title-group.article-title: Book Review: Technologies of History: Visual Media and the Eccentricity of the Past

contrib-group.aff: George Washington University, Washington, DC, USA

article-meta.product: Technologies of History: Visual Media and the Eccentricity of the Past. AndersonSteve F. Hanover, NH: Dartmouth College Press/University Press of New England “Interfaces: Studies in Visual Culture” Series, 2011. pp. $85 hbk. $35 pbk.

permissions.copyright-holder: Association for Education in Journalism & Mass Communication

body.p: This study offers a discussion of historiography in visual media, with an emphasis on alternate or fantastic histories—including Star Trek time-travel episodes, fake documentaries, films created from home movies and found footage, and video games about cultural traumas such as the FBI siege of the Branch Davidian compound at Waco, Texas, and the earlier 1963 JFK assassination.

Anderson, who directs the PhD program in media arts and practice at the University of Southern California, provides a variety of theoretical approaches to assess how generations of visual media offer new ways to view—and reconsider—past events.

The book is really a collection of mini case studies of different productions—theatrical films, television coverage, home movies—offering varied views on “known” history. The intersection of changing media technology—video games being another obvious example included here—provides one undercurrent to the overall narrative. So does a sense of revisionist history as we gain perspective over time.
